diagnoses.name: Acute pericarditis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the pericardium that develops suddenly.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition involving abnormally high levels of waste products in the blood, commonly resulting from kidney failure.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation throughout the body, potentially affecting the kidneys (lupus nephritis), and may lead to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Infective endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the endocardium, which is the inner lining of your heart chambers and heart valves, potentially leading to pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Renal failure
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the kidneys lose the ability to remove waste and balance fluids, which can cause uremic toxins to build up, potentially leading to delirium.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases in which the body's immune system attacks healthy cells, potentially leading to nephritis, pericarditis, and other organ-related symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.description: Certain types of cancers, especially those related to blood or immune system, can cause widespread symptoms, including pericardial effusion and renal impairment.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection that can spread to various parts of the body including the kidneys and the pericardium, causing nephritis and pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop after a Streptococcus bacterial infection and can cause inflammation of the heart, including the pericardium.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced lupus erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A lupus-like syndrome that is caused by certain prescription drugs, which may involve symptoms similar to lupus, including nephritis and pericarditis.

diagnoses: Cancer (various types, including lung cancer and lymphomas)
Lupus nephritis specifically (subset of SLE with kidney involvement)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A group of neurological disorders characterized by recurrent epileptic seizures. Given that seizures are a primary symptom, epilepsy is a likely consideration, though it doesn't directly explain the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, and in some cases, may lead to seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, leading to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. Symptoms can vary greatly but can include fatigue, and in rarer cases, angioedema and seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A common chronic respiratory condition that causes difficulty breathing due to inflammation and narrowing of the airways. Wheezing is a primary symptom, and fatigue can be a secondary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder characterized by unexpected episodes of swelling, particularly of the face and airways, and abdominal cramping. It does not typically cause wheezing, dysgeusia, or seizures but is directly related to angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Toxic exposure
diagnoses.description: Exposure to certain toxins or poisons can lead to a variety of nonspecific symptoms, including seizure disorders, wheezing (due to respiratory irritation), and dysgeusia. Fatigue is also a common nonspecific symptom of toxic exposure.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by the body's immune system attacking its own tissues, particularly the glands that produce saliva and tears. This can lead to dysgeusia due to dry mouth, along with fatigue. It is less commonly associated with seizure disorders or wheezing.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.description: An immune system response to a foreign substance that's not typically harmful to the body. Symptoms can include wheezing and angioedema. Fatigue can occur as a secondary symptom, especially in protracted allergic responses.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs. Amyloidosis can lead to symptoms such as fatigue, and in rare cases, might contribute to seizure disorders and dysgeusia.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 deficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from not enough vitamin B12 in the body, leading to a host of symptoms including fatigue, and potentially contributing to seizures. Dysgeusia can also occur as a symptom of the deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It may lead to symptoms like mood swings (mood lability) and dyspepsia, and can be associated with conditions that cause chronic pain such as vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Anxiety can manifest in various physical symptoms, including hypertension, mood lability, and digestive issues such as dyspepsia. Anxiety might exacerbate or contribute to conditions like otitis media and vulvodynia through stress-induced inflammation or by affecting pain perception.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: Depression is a common mental disorder that causes depressed mood, loss of interest, feelings of guilt or low self-worth, disturbed sleep or appetite, low energy, and poor concentration. Patients might experience symptoms such as mood lability, dyspepsia, and can report chronic pain conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, manifesting in a wide range of symptoms, including hypertension, mood swings, and potentially contributing to conditions like vulvodynia through autoimmune-related nerve damage. Patients may also complain of dyspepsia due to gastrointestinal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including mood changes, pain (which can sometimes be interpreted as vulvodynia), and hypertension due to autonomic nervous system disruption.

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: POTS is a condition that affects circulation (blood flow). It involves the nervous system and is characterized by the body's inability to properly regulate blood flow and pressure, leading to hypertension, dizziness, and possibly mood swings and digestive issues like dyspepsia.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome (IBS)
diagnoses.description: IBS is a common disorder that affects the large intestine. Symptoms include cramping, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, diarrhea or constipation, or both. IBS doesn't directly cause vulvodynia, otitis media, or hypertension but can be part of a broader pattern of dyspepsia and mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Myofascial Pain Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This is a chronic pain disorder. In this condition, pressure on sensitive points in your muscles (trigger points) causes pain in seemingly unrelated parts of your body. It can be associated with mood changes and contribute to the development of conditions like vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders of the thyroid, such as hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, can cause a wide range of symptoms, including mood lability, hypertension, and dyspepsia. Thyroid dysfunction can indirectly affect the incidence of conditions like otitis media through immunomodulation and changes in tissue physiology.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: PCOS is a condition that affects a woman's hormone levels, leading to a variety of symptoms, including mood changes, hypertension, and possibly contributing to vulvodynia through hormonal imbalances. Patients with PCOS might also experience digestive issues as part of their symptomatology.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Vitamin Deficiency (e.g., Vitamin D or Vitamin B12 deficiency)

diagnoses.name: Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS)
diagnoses.description: A type of dysautonomia that affects the flow of blood through the body, causing a rapid increase in heart rate when standing.

diagnoses.name: Stress-Induced Cardiomyopathy
diagnoses.description: Also known as Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, it is a temporary heart condition often brought on by stressful situations and emotional stress.

diagnoses.name: Hypercholesterolemia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by very high levels of cholesterol in the blood, a form of dyslipidemia.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, it can lead to fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph glands, including lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition known for widespread pain, fatigue, and other symptoms. Vulvodynia and dysautonomias can be associated symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome/Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (CFS/ME)
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that cannot be explained by any underlying medical condition. Dysautonomias can be a part of its symptomatology.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: Chronic anxiety can exacerbate or trigger symptoms of dysautonomias and takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears. It can be associated with dysautonomic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues, often associated with dysautonomias due to autonomic dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. It can cause lymphadenitis, dysautonomias, and various other symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) with acute exacerbation

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption and a variety of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels, which can cause aneurysms and affect organ systems, leading to a wide range of symptoms including anxiety and tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing chronic inflammation in blood vessels throughout the body, which can lead to aneurysms and a variety of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes the body to absorb too much iron from the diet. The excess iron is stored in the organs, especially the liver, heart, and pancreas, leading to hyperferritinemia and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)
diagnoses.description: A term for two conditions (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis) that are characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, causing malabsorption and a wide range of other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body’s connective tissue, leading to aneurysms, particularly in the aorta, and other symptoms possibly including anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to any part of the body, including the nervous and cardiovascular systems, potentially leading to aneurysms and anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare bacterial infection that affects mostly the small intestine but can also affect other parts of the body, leading to a wide array of symptoms, including malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Lysosomal Acid Lipase Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic disorder that results in the build-up of fats in the liver, spleen, and other organs, leading to hyperferritinemia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes abnormal growth or development of cells in the walls of blood vessels that can lead to aneurysms, hypertension, and a range of other symptoms.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Lung

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder that affects multiple parts of the body, including the mouth which can explain the ulcers and oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: Can manifest cognitive dysfunction, attention deficit, and has been linked with increased risk for cardiovascular events like takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Associated with cognitive dysfunction and can cause widespread pain, potentially explaining oral pain.

diagnoses.name: Lupus (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can cause cognitive dysfunction, oral ulcers, and has been associated with increased cardiovascular risks.

diagnoses.name: Stress-related Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions like PTSD, acute stress disorder can lead to cognitive impairments, and are risk factors for takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Can lead to cognitive dysfunction and oral ulcers due to its role in maintaining healthy nerve cells and red blood cells.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder known for its hallmark symptoms of dry mouth (which could lead to oral pain) and dry eyes, but also associated with systemic symptoms including cognitive dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Can cause cognitive dysfunction and oral ulcers, alongside general fatigue and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Oral Lichen Planus
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory condition of the mucous membranes in the mouth which can cause oral pain and ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Both hyperthyroidism and hypothyroidism can lead to cognitive dysfunction and have been vaguely linked with cardiovascular problems, potentially impacting conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy.

diagnoses: Steroid Induced Hyperglycemia and Psychological Effects
Vitamin deficiency (such as Vitamin D or Vitamin C deficiency)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. Common symptoms include fatigue, joint pain, skin rashes, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints causing pain, swelling, and potential loss of function. Fatigue and increased susceptibility to infections are common.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. It may also cause joint pain and skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) infection can lead to AIDS and significantly compromise the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to infections, fatigue, and skin manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted by ticks. Symptoms can include fatigue, joint pain, and various skin rashes.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include fatigue, joint pain, and skin nodules.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia (HHT)
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to the development of abnormal blood vessels (angiomata). Symptoms can include bleeding, anemia, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the body's blood-forming tissues, including the bone marrow and the lymphatic system. Symptoms can include fatigue, frequent infections, and skin changes.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the blood vessels that can cause changes in the skin, weakness, fatigue, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donor bone marrow or stem cells attack the recipient. Symptoms can include skin rash, liver dysfunction, and joint pain.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Chronic Idiopathic Urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by the development of hives and dermographism, which might lead to symptoms such as skin lesions and easy bruising due to scratching.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.description: Common viral infections can lead to symptoms like laryngitis and decreased appetite, alongside other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A disorder causing immune dysregulation and failure of apoptotic mechanisms, leading to chronic lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and autoimmune conditions that can result in easy bruising and cyst formation.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: A condition that involves purpuric skin lesions, often associated with joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement. Dermatographism and easy bruising can be secondary symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder caused by prolonged exposure of the body's tissues to high levels of cortisol, leading to symptoms including easy bruising, decreased appetite, and appearance of cysts due to thinning skin and other tissue changes.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: An infectious illness typically caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, presenting with fever, sore throat (which can result in laryngitis), and fatigue, as well as decreased appetite and lymph node swelling.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Immune Thrombocytopenia
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by a low platelet count, leading to easy bruising and possibly the appearance of purpura or petechiae. Dermatographism can be present in some cases due to skin sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin K Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin K is crucial for blood clotting. Deficiency can cause easy bruising and bleeding. Although less directly related to the other symptoms, dietary deficiencies could lead to decreased appetite and impacts on skin health.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including dermatographism, easy bruising, and decreased appetite, due to its systemic impact.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: An inherited disorder characterized by recurrent episodes of severe swelling. Dermatographism and cysts can be associated symptoms due to tissue swelling and fluid accumulation.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Diabetes Mellitus – considering the glycemic lability.
Sjögren's Syndrome – due to the manifestation of xerosis as part of its symptomatology.
Iron Deficiency Anemia – which can cause thrombocytosis in some cases.
Esophageal Stricture – can be a cause of dysphagia.
Achalasia – especially relevant with dysphagia as a presenting symptom.
Hypothyroidism – can present with multiple non-specific symptoms including xerosis.
Chronic Kidney Disease – can lead to thrombocytosis and other systemic symptoms.
Upper Respiratory Tract Infection – could explain the coryza.
Polycythemia Vera – a blood disorder that can cause thrombocytosis.
Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) – could lead to symptoms of dysphagia.
Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck
Gastrointestinal Disorders (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes and dry mouth, which could correlate with blepharospasm due to decreased tear production. This condition may also lead to systemic issues such as vaginal dryness that could be related to vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders where part of the body's immune system is missing or does not function properly, which may lead to decreased immunoglobulins and increase susceptibility to infections like otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A disease of the autonomic nervous system that can cause blood pressure lability. It can also affect other parts of the body leading to various symptoms, potentially including those described.

diagnoses.name: Hormonal Imbalances
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as thyroid disorders, which can cause a wide variety of symptoms, including mood changes, temperature sensitivity, and potentially blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. While not directly causing the symptoms listed, fatigue can exacerbate or contribute to their severity.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Some patients report symptoms akin to vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. It can sometimes present with symptoms like those described due to its systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease of the central nervous system that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including those affecting the eyes and potentially contributing to blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can be broad and affect multiple systems, potentially relating to the symptoms described.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: While typically more acute, severe or chronic allergic reactions can sometimes manifest with a variety of symptoms, including those affecting the skin, eyes, and potentially influencing immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses: Asthma (reactive airway disease, with a component of allergy-induced symptoms)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD, including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Hormonal imbalances causing flushing (e.g., menopause, carcinoid)
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Carbohydrate malabsorption (e.g., lactose intolerance, fructose malabsorption)
Anaphylactic Shock due to Food Allergy

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. Symptoms can include hives, abdominal cramps, difficulty breathing (leading to hypoxia), and swelling of the face, lips, and throat (angioedema).

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing sudden episodes of swelling (angioedema), which can occur in various parts of the body, including the abdomen, face, limbs, and airway. Abdominal cramps and hypoxia can result from swelling in the intestines and airway respectively.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reaction
diagnoses.description: A response of the immune system to a foreign substance (allergen) that's not typically harmful to the body. Symptoms can include hives, abdominal cramps, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Urticaria (Chronic)
diagnoses.description: Also known as chronic hives, this condition is characterized by red, itchy welts on the skin that last for six weeks or more. Associated symptoms can include abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections. Symptoms can include hypoxia, a sudden onset of high fever, diarrhea, a rash resembling sunburn, muscle aches, and abdominal cramps.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate activation of mast cells, which can result in a wide range of symptoms including hives, abdominal cramps, incontinence, and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Infection
diagnoses.description: Infections of the gastrointestinal tract can cause symptoms such as abdominal cramps, incontinence (due to urgency or diarrhoea), and in severe cases, hypoxia if the body's oxygen transport is compromised by dehydration or sepsis.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food. Symptoms can include hives, abdominal cramps, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Insect Sting Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction to the venom of stinging insects. Besides hives and angioedema, severe reactions can lead to anaphylaxis, which may include symptoms like abdominal cramps and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Drug Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction to a medication. Symptoms can range from mild rash (hives) to severe conditions like anaphylaxis, which can include abdominal cramps, hypoxia, and angioedema.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Food Allergies or Intolerances (e.g., lactose intolerance)
Anaphylaxis (especially if hypoxia and incontinence are acute and severe)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A migraine can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Sometimes called a ministroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief period of symptoms similar to those in a stroke. A TIA doesn't cause permanent damage. They are warning symptoms of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barré syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: Peripheral neuropathy, a result of damage to the nerves outside of the brain and spinal cord (peripheral nerves), often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms might include headache, fever, and a focal neurological deficit, such as weakness or numbness of a limb.

diagnoses.name: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Intracerebral hemorrhage is a type of stroke caused by a bleeding within the brain tissue itself — a life-threatening situation. Symptoms can vary depending on the location of the bleeding but can include sudden headache, weakness, numbness, and difficulty speaking.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear about 20 to 60 minutes before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Brain tumors can be benign (noncancerous) or malignant (cancerous).

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, but usually lasting only a few minutes and causing no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulging, weakened area in the wall of an artery in the brain, resulting in an abnormal widening or ballooning. If ruptured, it can cause bleeding into the space around the brain.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Circulatory Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders affecting the blood flow to the back of the brain, which can lead to symptoms including dizziness, double vision, weakness, and others.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: A form of cognitive impairment that involves a progressive loss of language function.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi sensu lato transmitted to humans through the bite of infected blacklegged ticks.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances (such as scotoma), sensory symptoms, aphasia, and often followed by migraine headache.
diagnoses.treatment: Pain relief medications, preventative medications, lifestyle changes.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death, causing symptoms like aphasia, and sometimes headache, depending on the area affected.
diagnoses.treatment: Immediate medical attention, clot-busting drugs, and sometimes surgery to remove the clot.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, including headache, aphasia, and possibly visual problems like scotoma.
diagnoses.treatment: Medications to prevent blood clots, control symptoms, and sometimes surgery to open narrowed arteries.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can cause headaches, vomiting, aphasia, and seizures.
diagnoses.treatment: Varies based on type and location, including surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, and in severe cases, aphasia.
diagnoses.treatment: Antibiotics for bacterial meningitis, and supportive care for viral meningitis.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often caused by a viral infection. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, aphasia, and seizures.
diagnoses.treatment: Antiviral medications, supportive care, and sometimes steroids.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include visual disturbances, aphasia, and sometimes headaches.
diagnoses.treatment: No cure, but treatments can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression. Treatments include disease-modifying therapies and symptom management.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, aphasia, and seizures.
diagnoses.treatment: Antibiotics and sometimes surgery to drain the abscess.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of blood vessels, often in the head, that can cause headaches, vision problems, and sometimes symptoms like aphasia if it affects certain arteries.
diagnoses.treatment: High doses of corticosteroid medications to reduce inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding within the skull that can lead to increased pressure, causing headache, vomiting, possible aphasia, and other symptoms depending on the hemorrhage location.
diagnoses.treatment: Surgical intervention to relieve pressure in the brain, medications to control symptoms, and supportive care.

diagnoses: Viral Infections (e.g., Dengue Fever, Zika Virus)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to glomerulonephritis
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Immune Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis without other clear autoimmune or rheumatological cause)
Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with multiple symptoms including malar rash (butterfly rash), discoid rash, leukopenia, nonscarring alopecia, and neuropsychiatric manifestations such as psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Discoid Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting the skin, causing discoid rash and nonscarring alopecia, systemic involvement can occasionally lead to hematologic abnormalities like leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Psychosis
diagnoses.rationale: A severe neuropsychiatric manifestation of SLE, which could co-exist with the skin manifestations and hematologic symptoms mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder exhibits features of various connective tissue diseases including lupus. Patients might present with malar rash, discoid rash, leukopenia, and occasionally psychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain drugs can induce lupus-like symptoms, including discoid and malar rashes, leukopenia, and potentially psychiatric symptoms, though nonscarring alopecia is less common.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily characterized by muscle weakness and skin rash, it can occasionally present with symptoms that overlap with lupus such as rashes and hematologic abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Schizophrenia
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily a psychiatric disorder characterized by psychosis. If co-occurring with unrelated dermatologic and hematologic conditions, the combination of symptoms could be coincidental rather than syndromic.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: This multisystem inflammatory disease can cause nonscarring alopecia and skin lesions that might resemble lupus, alongside systemic symptoms like leukopenia due to bone marrow involvement.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that mainly affects the joints but can also have systemic manifestations including hematologic abnormalities (leukopenia), skin rashes, and very rarely, psychiatric symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. It can present with skin lesions, though typically not malar or discoid rashes, and can have associated hematologic abnormalities such as leukopenia.

diagnoses: Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B related vasculitis, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.details: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and damage to joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints, but can also cause systemic effects including anemia and vasculitis, which could manifest as nasal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder with features of three other connective tissue diseases: lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis; it can present with hemolytic anemia, pericarditis, and other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It can be associated with other autoimmune disorders that cause the symptoms listed.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, including the heart and skin. It can present with mouth and nasal ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Wegener's Granulomatosis (Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.details: An uncommon disorder that causes vasculitis, which can lead to symptoms like nasal ulcers and kidney problems.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.details: A disease that causes inflammation of small and medium-sized arteries in the body, potentially affecting various organs, including the heart and skin.

diagnoses.name: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
diagnoses.details: An autoimmune disorder characterized by asthma, high levels of eosinophils, and vasculitis affecting various organs.

diagnoses.name: Microscopic Polyangiitis
diagnoses.details: A vasculitis affecting small blood vessels, which can cause renal issues, lung bleeding, and can be associated with autoimmunity.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.details: A lupus-like syndrome caused by certain prescription drugs that usually resolves after the medication is stopped. It can present with symptoms similar to SLE.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Microscopic Polyangiitis, Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Vasculitis (e.g., microscopic polyangiitis, eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Leukemia (e.g., chronic lymphocytic leukemia, acute lymphoblastic leukemia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect multiple systems including the skin, joints, blood, and nerves, causing a wide range of manifestations like nonscarring alopecia, hemolytic anemia, arthropathy, and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can cause systemic issues such as anemia and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth. It is associated with systemic features, including arthralgia, peripheral neuropathy, and hematologic changes.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause nonscarring alopecia, peripheral neuropathy due to granulomatous infiltration, and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A less specific term, often referring to a broader spectrum of autoimmune diseases including SLE, which can present with similar systemic symptoms such as skin changes, joint involvement, anemia, and neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. It is associated with systemic features including hemolytic anemia, arthropathy due to muscle inflammation, and occasionally, peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease causing small and medium-sized arteries to become swollen and damaged. It can lead to systemic issues like peripheral neuropathy, skin lesions, muscle and joint pain, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features of several connective tissue diseases like lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis including skin, joint, muscle, and vascular involvement, alongside hematological abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Refers to conditions that involve inflammation in the blood vessels, which can cause a variety of systemic symptoms depending on the vessels and organs involved, including peripheral neuropathy, anemia, and arthropathy.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver. While primarily affecting the liver, associated autoimmune responses can lead to symptoms like arthralgia and peripheral neuropathy.

diagnoses: Lupus Erythematosus with Nervous System Involvement
Lupus-like syndromes due to medications (Drug-induced Lupus)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
